item.title: Fortnite Rumored to Be Working on a Minecraft Collab
item.content:encoded:
A new rumor has emerged online suggesting that Fortnite may be collaborating with Minecraft.

Fortnite is a major player in the realm of collaborations within the gaming industry, partnering not only with various media franchises but also with different games. In the past, we have seen characters from iconic games such as God of War, Halo, Street Fighter, Resident Evil, and more appear in Fortnite. Now, it appears the devs may be collaborating with one of the largest games of all time, Minecraft.

Fortnite x Minecraft Seemingly in Early Development

The information about Fortnite‚Äôs Minecraft being in early development comes from X user (formerly Twitter) AdiraFNInfo, which was reposted by reliable Fortnite leaker HYPEX. However, HYPEX‚Äôs post has the word ‚Äòrumored‚Äô in it, which means that they haven‚Äôt been able to confirm whether this is indeed true. At the same time, if this is true, it could go down in the books as one of the biggest Fortnite collaborations of all time.

Fortnite has definitely levelled up their collaborations game over time, from just introducing skins, to introducing mythics and special abilities, and now designing their Island inspired by the collab. If Minecraft gets a similar treatment, we might see the Island adopt Minecraft‚Äôs unique art style. We could also see skins like Steve and other items make it into the game. However, this is just speculation, and readers should take this information with a massive grain of salt.

In other news, another claim states that Fortnite could be collaborating with The Office. Additionally, here are the patch notes for the January 9 39.20 update. Do you think Fortnite‚Äôs Minecraft collaboration is in early development? Leave your thoughts down in the comments, and join the official Insider Gaming Discord server.

item.title: Throwback Disney Collection Gets Nintendo Switch ESRB Rating
item.content:encoded:
If you‚Äôre in the mood for some ‚Äô80s and ‚Äô90s nostalgia, grab some Dunkaroos and get ready to be transported back to the world of Disney Afternoon cartoons on the Nintendo Switch family of consoles.

Back in 2017, Capcom released the Disney Afternoon Collection. Originally developed by Digital Eclipse, the game featured six classic NES games based on Disney cartoons from the 1980s and 1990s. The six included games were: Darkwing Duck, TaleSpin, two Chip‚Äôn Dale Rescue Rangers games, and two DuckTales games. Now, nine years after its original release, the game could finally come to the Nintendo Switch

A New ESRB Rating Has Surfaced

Atari, which now owns Digital Eclipse, has an ESRB rating for the collection of games specifically on the Nintendo Switch and Nintendo Switch 2. It‚Äôs not shocking that any Disney game would receive an E for Everyone rating, but fans can read the full rating description below:

The Disney Afternoon Collection is rated E for Everyone by the ESRB with Mild Fantasy Violence and Use of Tobacco. This is a collection of action platformer games from classic Disney franchises. Several games depict instances of mild, fantastical violence: players stunning enemies; characters shooting enemies; players throwing objects (e.g., boxes, rocks) at enemies; a plane shooting down enemy planes. Some games contain larger bosses and boss rush modes. One boss is depicted holding a cigar.

There is no proposed Switch release date for the NES game collection at this time. However, it is available on PlayStation and Xbox consoles, as well as PC, for anyone looking to scratch that nostalgic itch right now.

Insider Gaming will continue to follow the story and report any updates.

Would you purchase this collection again on the Nintendo Switch? Sound off in our official Discord server. Also, don‚Äôt forget to sign up for our weekly newsletter.

item.title: Xbox Updates Safer Gaming Commitment With Nintendo And Sony
item.content:encoded:
Xbox has provided an update to its ‚ÄúShared Commitment to Safer Gaming,‚Äù which it has partnered on with Nintendo and Sony Interactive Entertainment.

Xbox first announced the collaboration in 2020, noting that it partnered with its traditional competitors because it believes more can be accomplished when working together. Gaming, like any major community, is an excellent way for people to connect, but it also raises safety concerns.

Highlights Of The Commitment To Safer Gaming

In the update, written by Kim Kunes, the Vice President of Gaming Trust and Safety, the latest guidelines agreed upon by the three organizations were outlined. Fans can read the complete outline on the official Xbox Wire website, but below are some highlights:

Partnership: We partner with industry peers, publishers, regulators, law enforcement, and our communities to advance player safety.

We partner and engage with global and regional industry trade organizations, industry members, regulators, law enforcement, non-profit organizations, and experts to develop and/or advance online safety initiatives. These include Thriving in Games Group, the Family Online Safety Institute, and others.

We invest in leading technology and proactive collaboration to help thwart improper conduct and content. We participate in key industry initiatives, including the Tech Coalition and its Lantern program, that are dedicated to enhancing child safety through technology, knowledge-sharing, and transparency.

Roblox is one of the games that have recently come under fire for child safety concerns; in fact, the state of Louisiana is suing Roblox over these concerns.

Xbox is not just working with Nintendo and Sony on player safety. More of the Microsoft console‚Äôs exclusive games are appearing on PlayStation and Nintendo platforms as Xbox continues to push the narrative that everything is an Xbox.

item.title: Two Months Later, Only 10,000 Escape from Tarkov Players Have Finished the Game
item.content:encoded:
Two months ago, Escape from Tarkov hit 1.0 and was officially released as a full game. It was the most monumental milestone in the studio‚Äôs history, and the game‚Äôs director called it the most significant moment of his life. The release of Tarkov 1.0 introduced the game‚Äôs ultimate ending, achievable after completing an all-new campaign.

Fast forward to today, and just 10,489 players have managed to complete the game. It‚Äôs not known exactly how many people play Escape from Tarkov, but on Steam alone, you typically have around 25,000 concurrent players at peak times ‚Äì and that‚Äôs the minority platform by far.

How Many People Have Completed Escape from Tarkov?

In a post on social media, Nikita Buyanov, the head of the studio at Battlestate Games, confirmed that, at the time of writing, 10,489 players had escaped from Tarkov. When Escape from Tarkov hit 1.0 in November, this became the ultimate goal for fans worldwide, but also emerged as one of the toughest challenges ever presented in the extraction shooter space.

To make it to the game‚Äôs ending, an entire campaign with some hefty quests must be completed, and players then need to contend with a final ‚Äògauntlet‚Äô through a new map, Terminal. This is the final mission and arguably the toughest thing Tarkov players have ever faced.

If that wasn‚Äôt enough, players need to escape from boarding a boat, but depending on their squad size, not everyone is guaranteed a spot on said vessel. That means that, for one or two players, it‚Äôs a trip back to the lobby and a second go at the final gauntlet.

It took two weeks for the first player in the world, Tigz, to successfully escape from Tarkov. He did this while streaming live, and the broadcast was tuned into by several Battlestate Games employees, including Buyanov himself.

Many players have followed in his footsteps, but 10,489 users represent a serious minority group in the assumed millions of Escape from Tarkov owners. In August 2025, Nikita gave fans a glimpse at how many people were playing Escape from Tarkov PvP on a random Sunday evening, and the number was around 45,000.

That doesn‚Äôt include PvE, which should equal another 30,000 ‚Äì 40,000 (if Nikita‚Äôs PvE player count claims are accurate). That means almost 100,000 concurrent players were enjoying Tarkov on a Sunday evening, and extrapolation means that just 10% of those players would have completed the game, two months after the opportunity became available.

We can safely say very few Tarkov players have managed to accomplish the ultimate goal.

Have you managed to escape from Tarkov yet? Let us know what ending you got on the Insider Gaming Discord server.

item.title: Legacy of Kain Creator Reveals New Game ‚ÄòDeadhaus Sonata‚Äô 30 Years Later
item.content:encoded:
In 1996, Denis Dyack created Blood Omen: Legacy of Kain, a game that would go on to spawn another four titles over the next seven years. The series license was secured by Crystal Dynamics in the late nineties, pulling control away from Dyack, who would then go on to direct and produce Eternal Darkness: Sanity‚Äôs Requiem, Metal Gear Solid: Twin Snakes, and Too Human.

Tomorrow, Denis Dyack will be fully unveiling his new game, dubbed a spiritual successor to Legacy of Kain arriving 30 years later. It‚Äôs called Deadhaus Sonata, and it‚Äôs an action RPG being pieced together by Apocalypse Studios. On social media, the team shared a short trailer, and the title is available to wishlist and examine closer on Steam.

Deadhaus Sonata ‚Äì ‚ÄòThe Dead Do Not Sleep Forever‚Äô

The Deadhaus Sonata team published a short trailer for their upcoming narrative-driven RPG on social media, showcasing some of the gameplay mechanics. The account was established way back in 2018, so the game has been in development for quite some time.

Fans of a vampiric tale will be enthused by Deadhaus Sonata‚Äôs blurb:

The creator of Legacy of Kain is back. Become the undead in a third-person narrative-driven action RPG where your choices shape your legend and the world around you. Feed to grow stronger, embrace powerful classes, and carve your path alone or in co-op through a dark realm filled with secrets.

There‚Äôs no release date yet for Deadhaus Sonata, but the game is being more fully unveiled tomorrow. What we do know is that it‚Äôll be coming first to early access, allowing players to ‚Äòbecome the undead‚Äô and assume control of a powerful vampire with supernatural abilities.

The marketing spiel for Deadhaus Sonata is ambitious and promises a lot:

Deadhaus Sonata is a new dark fantasy world shaped by psychological depth, interconnected lore, and player-driven consequence. Every choice leaves a mark on your character and the world around you, with sentient gear, persistent events, and outcomes shaped by time, place, and action.

While the game can be wishlisted on Steam now, the title‚Äôs website stresses that it‚Äôll be available on ‚Äòall major platforms.‚Äô

Does Deadhaus Sonata look like your kind of game? Let us know what you‚Äôre thinking about it on the Insider Gaming Discord server.

item.title: Harry Potter VR Game Canceled By Meta, It‚Äôs Claimed
item.content:encoded:
Meta recently canceled a Harry Potter VR game following multiple studio closures and layoffs.

Gamertag VR on YouTube claimed that one of the games affected by the recent shake-ups in Meta‚Äôs gaming department was the Harry Potter game, which would have been developed by Skydance.

‚ÄúMeta cancelled several exclusive games, one of which was going to be a Harry Potter official VR game,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúIt was being made by Skydance.‚Äù

The Future Of Harry Potter Games Is Safe

Although the VR game has been canceled, the world of Hogwarts will continue in video games, as the sequel to Hogwarts Legacy, a Harry Potter-inspired MMO, is in development. To date, Hogwarts Legacy has sold over 40 million copies. The upcoming sequel could feature online multiplayer elements, according to a new job listing.

It was previously announced that four Meta Studios had faced either closures or layoffs: Twisted Pixel, Supernatural, Armature Studio, and Sanzaru Games. Across those four studios, more than 200 people were laid off. Learn more about that here.
